OLIGOPOLY
Compared to monopolistic competition, an oligopoly market has higher barriers to entry
and fewer firms. The other key difference is that the firms are interdependent, so a price
change by one firm can be expected to be met by a price change by its competitors. This
means that the actions of another firm will directly affect a given firm's demand curve for
the product. Given this complicating fact, models of oligopoly pricing and profits must
make a number of important assumptions. In the following, we describe four of these
models and their implications for price and quantity:
1. Kinked demand curve model.
